message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: State of the Art in Software Verification and Witness Validation: SV-COMP 2024
Paper Abstract: Abstract The 13th edition of the Competition on Software Verification (SV-COMP 2024) was the largest competition of its kind so far: A total of 76 tools for verification and witness validation were compared. The competition evaluated 59 verification systems and 17 validation systems from 34 teams from 12 countries. This yields a good overview of the state of the art in tools for software verification. The competition was executed on a benchmark set with 30 300 verification tasks for C programs and 587 . verification tasks for Java programs. The specifications again included reachability, memory safety, overflows, and termination. This year was the second time that the competition had an extra competition track on witness validation. We introduced a new witness format 2.0, and a new scoring schema for the validation track. All meta data about the verification and validation tools are available in the FM-Tools repository.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about memory safety:

## Definition

Memory safety is the state of being protected from various software bugs and security vulnerabilities when dealing with memory access, such as buffer overflows and dangling pointers.

## Examples of Memory-Safe vs Unsafe Languages

Java is said to be memory-safe because its runtime error detection checks array bounds and pointer dereferences. In contrast, C and C++ allow arbitrary pointer arithmetic with pointers implemented as direct memory addresses with no provision for bounds checking, and thus are potentially memory-unsafe.

## Significance of Memory Safety Issues

Memory safety is a critical concern in cybersecurity. In 2019, a Microsoft security engineer reported that 70% of all security vulnerabilities were caused by memory safety issues. Similarly, in 2020, a team at Google reported that 70% of all "severe security bugs" in Chromium were caused by memory safety problems.

## Approaches to Ensure Memory Safety

Different programming approaches provide varying levels of memory safety:

- When combined with automatic bounds checking on all array accesses and no support for raw pointer arithmetic, garbage collected languages provide strong memory safety guarantees.

- The Rust programming language implements a borrow checker to ensure memory safety, while C and C++ provide no memory safety guarantees.

Here's what I found about the C programming language:

## Overview

C is a general-purpose programming language.(no content)It was created in the 1970s by Dennis Ritchie and remains widely used and influential.

## Key Characteristics

C is an imperative procedural language, supporting structured programming, lexical variable scope, and recursion, with a static type system.(no content)By design, C gives the programmer relatively direct access to the features of the typical CPU architecture, customized for the target instruction set.(no content)It was designed to be compiled to provide low-level access to memory and language constructs that map efficiently to machine instructions, all with minimal runtime support. At the same time, the language was designed to encourage cross-platform programming. A standards-compliant C program written with portability in mind can be compiled for a wide variety of computer platforms and operating systems with few changes to its source code.

## Popularity and Standards

It has become one of the most widely used programming languages, with C compilers available for practically all modern computer architectures and operating systems.(no content)Since 2000, C has typically ranked as the most or second-most popular language in the TIOBE index.(no content)C has been standardized since 1989 by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) and, subsequently, jointly by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC).

Web search results for query: "Java programming language"

Links: [{"title":"Java (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Category:Java programming language family - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Java_programming_language_family"},{"title":"Talk:Java (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Java_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Outline of the Java programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_the_Java_programming_language"},{"title":"Self (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Mesa (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesa_(programming_language)"},{"title":"General-purpose programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General-purpose_programming_language"},{"title":"Smalltalk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smalltalk"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Java_(programming_language)/Selected_article"},{"title":"Talk:Java (programming language)/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Java_(programming_language)%2FArchive_1"}]

## Search Results for Java Programming Language

I found comprehensive information about Java. Here's a summary of the key details:

### Overview
Java is a high-level, general-purpose, memory-safe, object-oriented programming language.(no content)It is intended to let programmers write once, run anywhere (WORA), meaning that compiled Java code can run on all platforms that support Java without the need to recompile.

### History
James Gosling, Mike Sheridan, and Patrick Naughton initiated the Java language project in June 1991.(no content)Java was originally designed for interactive television, but it was too advanced for the digital cable television industry at the time. The language was initially called Oak after an oak tree that stood outside Gosling's office. Later the project went by the name Green and was finally renamed Java, from Java coffee, a type of coffee from Indonesia.(no content)Sun Microsystems released the first public implementation as Java 1.0 in 1996.

### How It Works
This is achieved by compiling the Java language code to an intermediate representation called Java bytecode, instead of directly to architecture-specific machine code. Java bytecode instructions are analogous to machine code, but they are intended to be executed by a virtual machine (VM) written specifically for the host hardware.

### Popularity
According to a study, C, Python, and Java were the most commonly used programming languages in 2021.

I've performed a web search for "software verification." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

Software verification is a discipline of software engineering, programming languages, and theory of computation whose goal is to assure that software satisfies the expected requirements.

## Verification vs. Validation

It's important to distinguish between verification and validation:

- Software verification asks the question, "Are we building the product right?"; that is, does the software conform to its specifications?
- Software validation asks the question, "Are we building the right product?"; that is, does the software do what the user really requires?

## Two Main Approaches

There are two fundamental approaches to verification: Dynamic verification, also known as experimentation, dynamic testing or, simply testing, which is good for finding faults (software bugs). Static verification, also known as analysis or, static testing - This is useful for proving the correctness of a program.

## Formal Verification

In computer science, formal methods are mathematically rigorous techniques for the specification, development, analysis, and verification of software and hardware systems.(no content)Formal verification of software programs involves proving that a program satisfies a formal specification of its behavior.

These search results provide comprehensive information about software verification concepts, approaches, and practical applications in software development.

## Reachability Analysis

Here are the search results for "reachability analysis":

### Distributed Systems Context

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the particular context of distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system consisting of local entities that communicated by the exchange of messages.(no content)The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.

### Broader Mathematical Context

More broadly, reachability is a fundamental problem which can be formulated as follows: Given a computational system with a set of allowed rules or transformations, decide whether a certain state of a system is reachable from a given initial state of the system.

### Applications

Reachability analysis has applications in several domains:

- **Program Analysis**: Context-free language reachability is an algorithmic problem with applications in static program analysis, where the problem is to determine whether there exists a path through a graph such that the concatenation of labels along the path is a string accepted by a context-free grammar.

- **Petri Nets**: Analysis of Petri nets can be performed by means of constructing either reachable state spaces (or reachable markings) or via the process of graph-based unfolding.

### Challenges

A practical issue of reachability analysis is the so-called "state space explosion." If two entities of a protocol have 100 states each, and the medium may include 10 types of messages, up to two in each direction, then the number of global states in the reachability graph is bound by 100 million.

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Witness protection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witness_protection"},{"title":"Witness (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witness_(mathematics)"},{"title":"United States Federal Witness Protection Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WITSEC"},{"title":"Witness statement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witness_statement"},{"title":"Functional verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Witness-indistinguishable proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witness-indistinguishable_proof"},{"title":"Witness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witness"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about "formal verification witness":

## Key Concepts

**Formal Verification**: Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

**Witness in Mathematical Logic**: In mathematical logic, a witness is a specific value t to be substituted for variable x of an existential statement of the form ∃x φ(x) such that φ(t) is true. This is a fundamental concept that connects to formal verification.

**Witness-Indistinguishable Proofs**: In the context of cryptography and formal verification, a witness-indistinguishable proof (WIP) is a variant of a zero-knowledge proof for languages in NP, where the verifier will not be able to distinguish between provers that use different witnesses.

## Application

These concepts are relevant to formal verification because witnesses—as concrete values that satisfy logical formulas—are often used as evidence or certificates in formal verification systems. They help demonstrate that certain properties or conditions hold true for a system being verified.

Is there a more specific aspect of formal verification witnesses you'd like to know more about?

Web search results for query: "integer overflow buffer overflow"

Links: [{"title":"Integer overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_overflow"},{"title":"Buffer overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_overflow"},{"title":"Stack buffer overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_buffer_overflow"},{"title":"Overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overflow"},{"title":"Buffer overflow protection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_overflow_protection"},{"title":"Talk:Integer overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Integer_overflow"},{"title":"Buffer underrun - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_underrun"},{"title":"Arithmetic underflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic_underflow"},{"title":"Buffer over-read - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_over-read"},{"title":"Stack overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_overflow"}]

I've completed the web search for "integer overflow buffer overflow". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Integer Overflow

An integer overflow occurs when an arithmetic operation on integers attempts to create a numeric value that is outside of the range that can be represented in the space allocated for the result – either higher than the maximum or lower than the minimum representable value.(no content)Multiplying or adding two integers may result in a value that is unexpectedly small, and subtracting from a small integer may cause a wrap to a large positive value.

## Connection Between Integer Overflow and Buffer Overflow

The search results reveal an important security connection: If an overflowed value is used as the number of bytes to allocate for a buffer, the buffer will be allocated unexpectedly small, potentially leading to a buffer overflow which, depending on the use of the buffer, might in turn cause arbitrary code execution.

## Buffer Overflow

A buffer overflow occurs when data written to a buffer also corrupts data values in memory addresses adjacent to the destination buffer due to insufficient bounds checking.(no content)This can occur when copying data from one buffer to another without first checking that the data fits within the destination buffer.

These two vulnerabilities can be related in that an integer overflow can create conditions that lead to buffer overflows, making them both important security concerns in software development.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "benchmark software testing". Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Benchmarking

In computing, a benchmark is the act of running a computer program, a set of programs, or other operations, in order to assess the relative performance of an object, normally by running a number of standard tests and trials against it.

## Software Benchmarking

Software benchmarks are, for example, run against compilers or database management systems (DBMS).(no content)Benchmarks provide a method of comparing the performance of various subsystems across different chip/system architectures.

## Performance Testing

In software quality assurance, performance testing is in general a testing practice performed to determine how a system performs in terms of responsiveness and stability under a particular workload.(no content)It can also serve to investigate, measure, validate or verify other quality attributes of the system, such as scalability, reliability and resource usage.

## Types of Benchmarks

Benchmarks are designed to mimic a particular type of workload on a component or system. Synthetic benchmarks do this by specially created programs that impose the workload on the component. Application benchmarks run real-world programs on the system.

## Benchmarking Tools

Some notable tools include:
- Sysbench is a scriptable multi-threaded benchmarking tool designed for Linux systems that is most frequently used for database benchmarks, for example MySQL.
- Speedometer was originally developed by the WebKit team at Apple and released in 2014 and tests a browser's Web app responsiveness by timing simulated user interactions.

Web search results for query: "program termination analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Termination analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Termination_analysis"},{"title":"Size-change termination principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Size-change_termination_principle"},{"title":"T2 Temporal Prover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T2_Temporal_Prover"},{"title":"Total functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_functional_programming"},{"title":"Typestate analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Typestate_analysis"},{"title":"Termination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Termination"},{"title":"Halting problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halting_problem"},{"title":"Program analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_analysis"},{"title":"Shape analysis (program analysis) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shape_analysis_(program_analysis)"},{"title":"Exit status - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exit_status"}]

Here are the search results for "program termination analysis":

## Overview

Termination analysis involves determining the termination behaviour of a program depending on some unknown input. More broadly, automated termination analysis is a field of research focused on heuristics that can be used in an automated fashion to attempt to construct proof that programs halt.

## Key Concepts

**The Halting Problem Challenge**: The undecidability of the halting problem means that there cannot exist some algorithm which determines whether any given program stops after finitely many computation steps. However, given a specific algorithm and input, one can often show that it halts or does not halt as part of a correctness proof.

**Termination Proofs**: A termination proof is a type of mathematical proof that plays a critical role in formal verification because total correctness of an algorithm depends on termination. A simple, general method for constructing termination proofs involves associating a measure with each step of an algorithm, taken from the domain of a well-founded relation such as from the ordinal numbers. If the measure "decreases" according to the relation along every possible step of the algorithm, it must terminate.

## Specific Approaches

**Size-Change Termination Principle**: The size-change termination principle (SCT) guarantees termination for a computer program by proving that infinite computations always trigger infinite descent in data values that are well-founded.

**Practical Applications**: T2 Temporal Prover is an automated program analyzer developed in the Terminator research project at Microsoft Research. T2 aims to find whether a program can run infinitely (called a termination analysis) and supports nested loops and recursive functions, pointers and side-effects, and function-pointers as well as concurrent programs.
